headline.main: Smoking Law Didn't Hurt Nassau's Economy

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The dire predictions of economic disaster by representatives of the tobacco and restaurant industries and labor organizations in regard to the New York State Public Health Council's proposed smoking regulations are reminiscent of similar predictions when Nassau County's smoking ordinance was proposed. Having worked very closely with the Nassau Board of Health in formulating the regulations and following up on their effects, we can report that contrary to predictions there has been no adverse impact on the economy of Nassau County.

byline.original: By Laura Mansnerus and Katherine Roberts

docs.lead_paragraph: A new Government report appears to give ammunition to both sides in the growing battle over passive smoking. On the one hand, the authors of the study said last week, tobacco smoke was clearly established as a health risk for infants, young children and the nonsmoking wives and husbands of smokers.

headline.main: YOUNG PUT AT RISK BY OTHERS' SMOKE

byline.original: By JANE E. BRODY, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: An expert committee of the National Research Council reported today that passive smoking was a clearly established health risk for infants, young children and the nonsmoking spouses of cigarette smokers. The committee also found ample documentation for assertions that tobacco smoke results in a disagreeable, lingering odor and can seriously irritate the eyes, nose and throat of nonsmokers. The report was also significant for what it did not say. The committee said that much more research was needed to assess the hazards of passive smoking in the workplace and other public environments, areas that have been the focus of much recent regulatory and legislative attention as well as dissention from the tobacco industry.
